entry.title: MVC Pattern
entry.content:
Model Objects

Model objects encapsulate the data specific to an application and define the logic and computation that manipulate and process that data. For example, a model object might represent a character in a game or a contact in an address book. A model object can have to-one and to-many relationships with other model objects, and so sometimes the model layer of an application effectively is one or more object graphs. Much of the data that is part of the persistent state of the application (whether that persistent state is stored in files or databases) should reside in the model objects after the data is loaded into the application. Because model objects represent knowledge and expertise related to a specific problem domain, they can be reused in similar problem domains. Ideally, a model object should have no explicit connection to the view objects that present its data and allow users to edit that data‚Äîit should not be concerned with user-interface and presentation issues.

Communication: User actions in the view layer that create or modify data are communicated through a controller object and result in the creation or updating of a model object. When a model object changes (for example, new data is received over a network connection), it notifies a controller object, which updates the appropriate view objects.

View Objects

A view object is an object in an application that users can see. A view object knows how to draw itself and can respond to user actions. A major purpose of view objects is to display data from the application‚Äôs model objects and to enable the editing of that data. Despite this, view objects are typically decoupled from model objects in an MVC application.

Because you typically reuse and reconfigure them, view objects provide consistency between applications. Both the UIKit and AppKit frameworks provide collections of view classes, and Interface Builder offers dozens of view objects in its Library.

Communication: View objects learn about changes in model data through the application‚Äôs controller objects and communicate user-initiated changes‚Äîfor example, text entered in a text field‚Äîthrough controller objects to an application‚Äôs model objects.

Controller Objects

A controller object acts as an intermediary between one or more of an application‚Äôs view objects and one or more of its model objects. Controller objects are thus a conduit through which view objects learn about changes in model objects and vice versa. Controller objects can also perform setup and coordinating tasks for an application and manage the life cycles of other objects.

Communication: A controller object interprets user actions made in view objects and communicates new or changed data to the model layer. When model objects change, a controller object communicates that new model data to the view objects so that they can display it.

entry.title: Delegate in iOS Develop
entry.content:
Defination

The delegate is an object(Control Object) that executes a group of methods on behalf of another object.

Control object is designed to pass user input to a data model.

We want view classes to be used as is, and then we want control and model classes to have the freedom to customize those views. The delegate pattern allows for this.

The key to the delegate pattern, is that the view establishes the questions that it needs answered and encodes them in a protocol.

A protocol is a list of methods that a delegate must implement.

Any object that fulfills the protocol can become a delegate.

UITextFieldDelegate protocol

Let‚Äôs take a closer look at the protocol we‚Äôll implement next, the UITextFieldDelegate protocol. We‚Äôve listed its methods below. For each of the seven methods, consult the documentation and provide an example implementation. Post one or two of your examples to the discussion forum.

Editing lifecycle methods:
textFieldShouldBeginEditing(_:)
textFieldDidBeginEditing(_:)
textFieldShouldEndEditing(_:)
textFieldDidEndEditing(_:)

textFieldShouldBeginEditing(_:)

You could use this method to prevent the user from editing the text field‚Äôs contents more than once.

textFieldDidBeginEditing(_:)

You might use this method to show overlay views that are visible only while editing.

textFieldShouldEndEditing(_:)

The text field calls this method when it is asked to resign the first responder status. This can happen when the user selects another control or when you call the text field‚Äôs resignFirstResponder() method. Before the focus change occurs, however, the text field calls this method and gives you a chance to prevent the change from happening.

Normally, you would return true from this method to allow the text field to resign the first responder status. You might return false, however, in cases where your delegate detects invalid contents in the text field. Returning false prevents the user from switching to another control until the text field contains a valid value.

If you use this method to validate the contents of the text field, you might also want to use an overlay view to provide feedback to that effect. For example, you might display a small icon indicating the text is invalid.

textFieldDidEndEditing(_:)

This method is called after the text field resigns its first responder status. You can use this method to update your delegate‚Äôs state information. For example, you might use this method to hide overlay views that should be visible only while editing.

The primary method for controlling text:
textField(_:shouldChangeCharactersIn:replacementString:)

  • textField

The text field containing the text.

  • range

The range of characters to be replaced.

  • string

The replacement string for the specified range. During typing, this parameter normally contains only the single new character that was typed, but it may contain more characters if the user is pasting text. When the user deletes one or more characters, the replacement string is empty.

  • The text field calls this method whenever user actions cause its text to change. Use this method to validate text as it is typed by the user. For example, you could use this method to prevent the user from entering anything but numerical values.

The clear button (the ‚Äòx‚Äô on the right side of some text fields):
textFieldShouldClear(_:)

The text field calls this method in response to the user pressing the built-in clear button. (This button is not shown by default but can be enabled by changing the value in the clearButtonMode property of the text field.) This method is also called when editing begins and the clearsOnBeginEditing property of the text field is set to true.

If you do not implement this method, the text field clears the text as if the method had returned true.

The return key in the keyboard:
textFieldShouldReturn(_:)

The default implementation returns true, resigning first responder status. You can override this method in your custom responders to update your object‚Äôs state or perform other actions, such as removing the highlight from a selection. You can also return false, refusing to relinquish first responder status. If you override this method, you must call super (the superclass implementation) at some point in your code.

Control Flow Walk-trough

  1. User taps keyboard

  2. Textfield realizes text will change

  3. Textfield invokes ‚Ä¶

    textField(_:shouldChangeCharactersIn:replacementString:)

  4. VC receives invocation

  5. VC assembles the new text

  6. VC updates the label

  7. VC returns ‚Äútrue‚Äù to allow change

We can‚Äôt see the first three steps.

Emoji Textfield

entry.title: XcodeÂø´Êç∑ÈîÆ
entry.content:
Xcode Shortcuts

Xcode has numerous keyboard shortcuts that are worth learning. Knowing them can help speed up your iOS development, and it saves you from having to reach over to the mouse or trackpad.

On the Navigator Panel on the left side, the following keyboard shortcuts cycle through the different navigators.

  • ‚åò + 0 = Show or Hide the Navigator Panel
  • ‚åò + 1 = Project
  • ‚åò + 2 = Source Control
  • ‚åò + 3 = Symbol
  • ‚åò + 4 = Find
  • ‚åò + 5 = Issue
  • ‚åò + 6 = Test
  • ‚åò + 7 = Debug
  • ‚åò + 8 = Breakpoint
  • ‚åò + 9 = Report

The Utility Area on the right side of Xcode can also be toggled with the following keyboard shortcuts:

  • ‚å• + ‚åò + 0 = Show or Hide the Utility Area
  • ‚å• + ‚åò + 1 = File Inspector
  • ‚å• + ‚åò + 2 = Quick Help Inspector
  • ‚å• + ‚åò + 3 = Identity Inspector
  • ‚å• + ‚åò + 4 = Attributes Inspector
  • ‚å• + ‚åò + 5 = Size Inspector
  • ‚å• + ‚åò + 6 = Connections Inspector

If you right click (control click) on the Storyboard in the editor, then you can select a zoom level. You can also use 2 finger pinch in your Mac‚Äôs trackpad to zoom in and out of the Storyboard.

entry.title: SwiftËøõÈò∂
entry.content:
Optionals

Nil value

The Nil value is the same as null in some other languages.

Another Example With Nested Structures

Safely unwrapping optionals is a fundamental Swift skill and one can‚Äôt have too much practice. Let‚Äôs walk through another example using the following enum and structures.

The Song struct contains a property artist of optional type Artist?. Then, the Artist struct as a primaryGenre property of optional type Genre?. Genre is a simple enumeration with only three cases for simplicity.

Now imagine we have the following instances of the Artist and Song structs. Here, johnny is assigned to the Artist property of walkTheLine.

If we only had access to the the Song instance walkTheLine and we wanted to determine the primaryGenre of the song‚Äôs artist, we‚Äôd need some if lets.

First, we‚Äôd need to get the artist.

And within the first if let, we‚Äôd use another to get the primaryGenre.

If the genre property of artist is not nil, we know it has a value and can safely print out the genre.

Example: Animals With and Without Tails

Here‚Äôs another example: let‚Äôs say we have a struct called Animal. The Animal struct has a tail property and the tail property is an optional ‚Äî not all animals have tails.

Nil Coalescing Operator

We already used optional chaining to avoid nesting if lets, but what if all we want to do is provide tailLength with a default value if the optional chaining fails? Swift provides a useful operator, for situations like these, the nil coalescing operator, ??.

To use the operator, simply place ?? after the optional chaining expression, and then put a default value after the ??.

Your Turn

Assume the following structs and enum are defined.

Using the enums and structures, implement the getArtistGenre() function. Given a Song as input, return the raw value of the artist‚Äôs primary genre. If either the artist is nil or the primaryGenre is nil, then return an empty string. You must use optional chaining and the nil coalescing operator (??).

Example: Revisiting the Int() Initializer Method

Let‚Äôs say we‚Äôre using the Int() initializer method and invoking it on a variable that we are confident can be converted to an Int.

We know this method is going to return the Int, 123, so in this case, unwrapping with the exclamation point is appropriate. We know there is little risk of a fatal error being thrown. We can place the exclamation point after w, like this:

Or we could unwrap the return value directly, like this:

In this second case the value assigned to w will be a plain old Int.

Implicitly Unwrapped Optionals: Revisiting the Villain struct

What about declaring implicitly unwrapped optionals? When is an appropriate time to be so bold? Well, remember the evilScheme property of the Villain struct? We wanted the ability to create instances of Villain with the option of not providing an evilScheme at first. However, once we know that the evilScheme has been set, we can access the property as if it were a regular non-optional type.

There are a few things to note in the example above.

  • The evilScheme property is now declared as an implicitly unwrapped optional. It‚Äôs type is written as String! instead of String?.
  • In the performScheme() method, we reference evilScheme as any other property, without unwrapping.
  • We call performScheme() once we know for a fact that evilScheme was set. The function assumes that evilScheme is not nil. If we treat an implicitly unwrapped optional that contains nil as if it contained a value, bad things can happen - including crashes!

Difference between upwrapping an with ?, with ! and with implicit unwrapping?

Unwrapping with ? is useful if you‚Äôre accessing nested properties or want some default behavior to occur if a value is nil.

Using ! does not require providing a default value and is useful if you know that a value won‚Äôt be nil. However, if it is nil, the program will crash.

Implicitly unwrapping optionals is also useful when you know a value won‚Äôt be nil, but you can use the same syntax as a normal property. However, unintended behavior and crashes can occur if it is nil.

Strings

A String is a Struct

You just saw how a string can be initialized without a string literal.

Counting Characters

Let‚Äôs start with something straightforward. If you want to know how many characters are in a string, you use the count property.

Many real apps rely on counting characters - for example, a Twitter client that ensures a user is restricted to typing 140 or fewer characters.

Accessing specific characters

We can also conveniently access the characters at the beginning and end of a string.

Checking for Substrings

A substring is the term programmers use for any string that occurs within another string. We can check for the presence of a substring in different cases as shown below.

contains() simply checks if the substring occurs anywhere in str. hasPrefix() and hasSuffix() are more specialized and check if the substring occurs at the beginning and end of the string respectively.

Creating Variations of Strings

We can also use some string methods to generate different strings.

Converting strings to all-lowercase or all-uppercase is great when you want user input to be case-insensitive. And reversing a string is useful if you want to see if two strings are palindromes.

Note in the last example, we need to use str.reversed() with a String initializer. If you look closely at the documentation for reversed(), you‚Äôll see that it actually returns a ReversedCollection instead of a String. You won‚Äôt need to use this type directly, but just know that Swift uses it ‚Äúunder the hood‚Äù for efficiency. You can simply use the String() initializer to convert the result into a usable string.

Appending Two Strings

Similar to concatenation, String also has an append() method that takes a string as an argument and attaches it to the string you‚Äôre mutating.

Is the equivalent of

or

With append() you don‚Äôt need to reassign hello a new value, and you‚Äôll find the code is much more readable.

Trimming characters

In addition to append(), we can also remove characters from the end of a string. For example, you may want to remove all whitespace characters from the end of a user‚Äôs input.

And the same can be done at the beginning.

Replacing Substrings

We can also modify the middle of strings. A common manipulation method is replacingOccurrences(of: String, with: String), which allows us to swap out one substring with another.

This method might come in handy for implementing a Find and Replace feature, a profanity filter, and many other cases, and is great to have in your string manipulation bag of tricks.

Note: To use the replaceOccurrences() method, you will need to add import Foundation to the top of your file. Foundation is a framework, which is just a name for a collection of commonly used code. Apple provides frameworks like Foundation so that developers, like you, don‚Äôt need to reinvent the wheel for common tasks like string manipulation. We‚Äôve already imported Foundation in the playground, so you can just follow along with the examples.

Array

Initialize

Append

Here is an array of type String, listing musicians we want to play in the car on our upcoming road trip. To add an item to the end of an array we can use the append method, like this:

The array now looks like this:

Insert

To add an item to a specific place in an array we can use the method, insert(at:). So, to add in ‚ÄúDej Loaf‚Äù at index 2 we would write the following:

The array now looks like this:

Remove

We can use a method called remove(at:) to remove an item at a particular index. If we remove the item at index 3, you can see that ‚ÄúFlo Rida‚Äù is removed:

Subscripting

Finally, if you want to retrieve an item at a particular index, you can use subscript syntax. Simply put the index in-between brackets after the array name, like so:

Dictionary

Initialize

Here we use the removeValueForKey() method to remove the value for the string, ‚ÄúGeorge Bush‚Äù. Since removeValueForKey() returns the value removed, we can reset the value of the new key, ‚ÄúGeorge H. W. Bush‚Äù to be the previously returned value, ‚ÄúMiss Beazley.‚Äù

We unwrap the retrieved value using if let and then use string interpolation to insert ‚ÄúBo‚Äù into the string. The string is printed out as a part of the if block.

Sets

Class

One important difference between structs and classes in Swift is how they‚Äôre handled in the computer or phone‚Äôs memory. Structs are passed by value while classes are passed by reference. Let‚Äôs see what this means with a simple example.

Class Inheritance

One powerful feature of classes not available to structs is inheritance. Inheritance allows one class to take on the properties and methods of another class, as well as add its own functionality.

To start, let‚Äôs say we have a Guitar class defined as the following.

This is a great start, but what if we then wanted to model an electric guitar. The electric guitar is a ‚Äúkind of‚Äù guitar, but with a few differences. For example, the electric guitar has electronics for modifying the volume and tone of its output (check out the knobs on the lower body). We could define a new ElectricGuitar class by copy-pasting the GuitarClass and adding these different properties, but we can do much better. Instead, if we place a colon after the the class name and then specify the class we want to inherit from, the ElectricGuitar automatically has all the properties and methods of a guitar.

Now we have a new class, ElectricGuitar that has all the properties of Guitar with the additional properties for volume and tone.

superclassA class that is inherited from
subclassA class that inherits from another class (the superclass)
parent classA class‚Äôs superclass
child classA class that descended (inherited directly) from a parent class.
descendantA class that inherited from an ancestor
ancestorA class that has child or descendent classes
root classA class with no superclass
leaf classA class with no subclasses
hierarchyA tree of inheritance relationships

Overriding Methods

Inheritance doesn‚Äôt just let you add to a class - you can also override its behavior. For example, since an electric guitar‚Äôs volume affects its sound, we can provide some custom functionality to the pluck() method.

Overriding a method is as simple as redeclaring it and adding the override keyword before func. And if you ever need to fall back to the original functionality, as we do in the case when the volume is 0, the old implementation can be called super keyword. super just refers to the superclass (the Guitar class we‚Äôre inheriting from) so super.pluck() will call the pluck() method of theGuitar` class which will print ‚Äútwang‚Äù.

Polymorphism

Inheritance, or the ability of one class to take on the properties and methods of a superclass, leads us to the next topic - polymorphism.

Polymorphism means ‚Äúmany forms.‚Äù It is a programming language feature by which a type can be substituted for another type. For example, since it inherits from a Guitar, an ElectricGuitar can be substituted anywhere that a Guitar would be used. In other words, an ElectricGuitar is a form of Guitar.

Polymorphism allows for simpler code that avoids unnecessary specificity, and code that is flexible and expandable because it‚Äôs applicable to more than one type. If we were to add additional subclasses of Guitar, we could still use any of these types where a Guitar is used.

override is used to indicate that a subclass‚Äôs method implementation will be substituted for a superclass‚Äôs method implementation. This is an aspect of polymorphism through inheritance.

We saw an example of polymorphism previously when we used override to refer to a single Guitar type, and produced different behavior by substituting in an ElectricGuitar instead of a Guitar.

We can see an example of polymorphism in action below. Because anyGuitar‚Äòs type is Guitar we can assign any subclass of Guitar, including an ElectricGuitar to that variable.

Even though anyGuitar()‚Äòs type is still Guitar, calling pluckString() will call the custom method we defined for ElectricGuitar. As a result, we can keep our code involving Guitar instances reusable, without sacrificing the functionality of any subclasses that happen to override a method.

Type Casting

Finally, if we know that anyGuitar is assigned an ElectricGuitar and we want to access the toneLevel property, we can convert the types with a special keyword: as. When using the as keyword the variable you want to convert goes on the left and the type you‚Äôre converting to goes on the right.

You‚Äôll also notice the use of as! and as? in this example. This may seem complicated but it‚Äôs really the same concept you learned about unwrapping optionals. Since there‚Äôs no guarantee that anyGuitar will actually be an ElectricGuitar, casting to an ElectricGuitar returns an optional of type Guitar?. To forcibly unwrap the result, we use as! and to conditionally unwrap with if let, we use as?.

Defining Terms

There‚Äôs some terminology to cover, and then we‚Äôll describe what happens when a method is called on a type that is defined as a class.

TermExampleDefinition
instanceGuitar()A class or type that we have initialized. Can be referred to with a constant or variable, and refers to its own instance with self
overrideoverride func pluckString() { }Used to indicate that this method implementation should supersede the superclass‚Äôs method implementation
supersuper.someMethod()Used to retrieve and invoke a method implementation that has been overridden

Protocols

Extensions

One more powerful feature of Swift types is the ability to add new methods and properties through extensions. You‚Äôll see extensions in action as you start building the Pitch Perfect app, so let‚Äôs take a look at an example before wrapping up with object oriented programming.

To extend a class, simply use the extension keyword, followed by the type name.

Additionally, you can also add a colon after the type name followed by any number of protocols you‚Äôd like the type to conform to. Let‚Äôs rewrite the Roommate example so that it uses an extension to conform to Souschef.

Isn‚Äôt this the same as the previous example? It is, but with extensions, you don‚Äôt even need access to the original class definition for Roommate. As you begin your journey into iOS development, you‚Äôll be working with many classes provided by Apple in which you do not have direct access to the code. However, with extensions you can add functionality to these types without ever modifying the original class definition.

Review

Something that is passed by value such as an instance of a struct is copied when it‚Äôs assigned to a variable or passed to a function. Changing a property on the instance will only apply to the copy, and the original instance will remain unchanged.

Values that are passed by reference, such as instances of classes, are not copied. Changing a value on a copy will also modify the original instance, since the copy is simply referencing the original.

BQ question 1

Tell me about yourself:

  1. Name, Education, Background
  2. Skills: Primary programming language, Projects experience, intern experience

ÂÆÖÂú®ÂÆ∂Ëøô‰πàÂ§öÂ§©ÔºåÈô§‰∫ÜÂÅ∂Â∞îÁöÑÈ¢àÊ§éÈÖ∏ÁóõÔºåÂ§ß‰Ωì‰∏äÈÉΩÂæàÂºÄÂøÉÔºå‰∏ªË¶ÅÊòØÂíåÁà∂ÊØçÊ≤üÈÄö‰∏∫‰∏ªÔºå‰∏∫Êï∞‰∏çÂ§öÁöÑÂíåÂà´‰∫∫‰∫§ÊµÅ‰πüÈÉΩÊòØÈÄöËøáÁΩëÁªúÔºåÊÑüËßâÂ∞ë‰∫ÜÂæàÂ§ö‰∏çÂøÖË¶ÅÁöÑÁÉ¶ÊÅº„ÄÇËá™Â∑±ÊØèÂ§©ÂÅöÁùÄËá™Â∑±ËÆ§‰∏∫ËØ•ÂÅöÁöÑ‰∫ãÔºåÂáÜÂ§áÊØîËµõ‰πüÂ•ΩÔºåÁúãÁúãÁõ¥Êí≠‰πüÁΩ¢ÔºåÈÉΩËÆ©Ëá™Â∑±ËßâÂæóËá™Â∑±ËøòÊ¥ªÁùÄÔºåÊ≤°Âú®ËôöÂ∫¶Ëá™Â∑±ÁöÑÂÖâÈò¥ÔºåÂíå‰∏äÂ≠¶ÂîØ‰∏ÄÁöÑÂå∫Âà´Â∞±ÊòØÔºåÊàëÂèØ‰ª•ÈöèÊÑèÁöÑÊéåÊéßÊàëËá™Â∑±ÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥ÔºåËá≥‰∫éÊïàÊûúÊÄé‰πàÊ†∑ÔºåÊàë‰πü‰∏çÂæóËÄåÁü•Ôºå‰ΩÜËá™Áî±ÊÄªÊòØÊúÄÂÆùË¥µÁöÑ„ÄÇ

Áõ¥Âà∞ËÄÉËØïÂâçÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂÖ≥‰∫éÂª∫Ê®°ÁöÑ‰∫ãÊÉÖËÅäÂæóÈÉΩ‰∏çÂ§öÔºåÊÑüËßâÊàë‰ª¨‰∏â‰∏™ÈÉΩÊòØÊØîËæÉÂÜÖÊïõÁöÑ‰∫∫ÔºåÊàëËøòÁÆóÊòØÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÊØîËæÉÂ§ñÂêëÁöÑ‰∫ÜÔºåÂæàÂ§öÊó∂ÂÄôÂ¶ÇÊûúÊàë‰∏çËØ¥ËØùÔºå‰º∞ËÆ°Áæ§ÈáåÂ∞±‰∏ç‰ºöÊúâ‰∫∫ËØ¥ËØù‰∫Ü„ÄÇËµ∂Âú®ÂØíÂÅáÂâçÊúüÊú´ËÄÉËØïÂêéÔºåÊàëÊâìÁÆóÂ•ΩÂ•ΩÂáÜÂ§á‰∏Ä‰∏ãÔºåËôΩÁÑ∂ÊÑüËßâÊØ´Êó†Â§¥Áª™Ôºå‰∏çÁü•ÈÅì‰ªéÂì™‰∏™È´òÊ∑±ÁöÑÁÆóÊ≥ïÂºÄÂßãÂ≠¶Ëµ∑Ôºå‰ΩÜËøòÊòØÁ°¨ÁùÄÂ§¥ÁöÆ‰∏äÔºå‰π∞‰∫Ü‰∏™ËØæÔºåÊØèÂ§©Âê¨‰∏ÄÂê¨ÔºåÂêéÊù•Â∞±ÂéªÂåó‰∫¨Â≠¶GRE‰∫ÜÔºåÊï∞Ê®°‰ªÄ‰πàÁöÑ‰πüÂ∞±ÊöÇ‰∏îÊêÅÁΩÆ‰∫ÜÔºåÁõ¥Âà∞ÊØîËµõÂâçÂá†Âë®ÔºåÊâçÁªßÁª≠Â≠¶‰∏Ä‰∫õÁü•ËØÜ„ÄÇÂøòËÆ∞ËØ¥‰∫ÜÔºå‰ªäÂπ¥ÊØîËæÉÁâπÊÆäÁöÑÊòØÔºåÂèóÁñ´ÊÉÖÂΩ±ÂìçÔºåÁæéËµõ‰ªé‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÊîπÊàê‰∫Ü‰∏§Ê¨°Ôºå‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÊòØ2Êúà‰ªΩÔºå‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÊòØ3Êúà‰ªΩÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂΩìÊó∂ÊÉ≥ÁùÄÊàñËÆ∏3ÊúàËÉΩÂºÄÂ≠¶ÔºåÂ∞±ÂéªÊêû3ÊúàÁöÑÊØîËµõÔºàÊàëÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏äÊòØËßâÂæóËá™Â∑±Âï•‰πü‰∏ç‰ºöÔºåËÉΩÊãñÂá†Â§©ÊòØÂá†Â§©ÔºåÊãñÔºåÂ∞±ÊÅ©ÊãñÔºâ

entry.title: Bit,Byte,K,M‰πãÈó¥ÁöÑÊç¢ÁÆóÈóÆÈ¢ò
entry.content:
BitÊÑè‰∏∫‚Äú‰Ωç‚ÄùÊàñ‚ÄúÊØîÁâπ‚ÄùÔºåÊòØËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ËøêÁÆóÁöÑÂü∫Á°ÄÔºåÂ±û‰∫é‰∫åËøõÂà∂ÁöÑËåÉÁï¥Ôºõ

ByteÁÆÄÂÜô‰∏∫BÔºåËÄåbitÁÆÄÂÜô‰∏∫bÔºõ1B=8bÔºõ

ÈóÆÈ¢òÔºöËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫Á°¨Áõò64GÔºåÊØè‰∏™ÂùóÁöÑÂ§ßÂ∞è‰∏∫4KÔºåÁî®‰ΩçÁ§∫ÂõæÊù•ÁÆ°ÁêÜÁ°¨ÁõòÁöÑÁ©∫Èó¥ÔºåÂàô‰ΩçÁ§∫ÂõæÁöÑÂ§ßÂ∞è‰∏∫Â§öÂ∞ëÂ≠óËäÇÔºü

  • 4M
  • 2M
  • 1M

Ëß£Á≠îÔºö
$$
\frac{64G}{4K}=\frac{64\times1024\times1024K}{4K}Ê¨°(bit)=\frac{16\times1024\times1024}{8\times1024\times1024}=2M
$$

entry.title: „ÄêSTM32„ÄëNVIC‰∏≠Êñ≠‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÁÆ°ÁêÜ
entry.content:
NVIC‰∏≠Êñ≠‰ªãÁªç

  • CM3ÂÜÖÊ†∏ÊîØÊåÅ256‰∏™‰∏≠Êñ≠ÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÂåÖÂê´‰∫Ü16‰∏™ÂÜÖÊ†∏‰∏≠Êñ≠Âíå240‰∏™Â§ñÈÉ®‰∏≠Êñ≠ÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÂÖ∑Êúâ256Á∫ßÁöÑÂèØÁºñÁ®ã‰∏≠Êñ≠ËÆæÁΩÆ„ÄÇ
  • STM32Âπ∂Ê≤°Êúâ‰ΩøÁî®CM3ÂÜÖÊ†∏ÁöÑÂÖ®ÈÉ®‰∏úË•øÔºåËÄåÊòØÂè™Áî®‰∫ÜÂÆÉÁöÑ‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÂàÜ„ÄÇ
  • STM32Êúâ84‰∏™‰∏≠Êñ≠ÔºåÂåÖÊã¨16‰∏™ÂÜÖÊ†∏‰∏≠Êñ≠Âíå68‰∏™ÂèØÂ±èËîΩ‰∏≠Êñ≠ÔºåÂÖ∑Êúâ16Á∫ßÂèØÁºñÁ®ãÁöÑ‰∏≠Êñ≠‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ß„ÄÇ
  • STM32F103Á≥ªÂàó‰∏äÈù¢ÔºåÂèàÂè™Êúâ60‰∏™ÂèØÂ±èËîΩ‰∏≠Êñ≠ÔºàÂú®107Á≥ªÂàóÊâçÊúâ68‰∏™Ôºâ

‰∏≠Êñ≠ÁÆ°ÁêÜÊñπÊ≥ï

È¶ñÂÖàÔºåÂØπSTM32‰∏≠Êñ≠ËøõË°åÂàÜÁªÑÔºåÁªÑ0~4„ÄÇÂêåÊó∂ÔºåÂØπÊØè‰∏™‰∏≠Êñ≠ËÆæÁΩÆ‰∏Ä‰∏™Êä¢Âç†‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÂíå‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂìçÂ∫î‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÂÄº„ÄÇ

ÂàÜÁªÑÈÖçÁΩÆÊòØÂú®ÂØÑÂ≠òÂô®SCB->AIRCR‰∏≠ÈÖçÁΩÆÔºö

Êä¢Âç†‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ß & ÂìçÂ∫î‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÂå∫Âà´

  • È´ò‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÁöÑÊä¢Âç†‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÊòØÂèØ‰ª•ÊâìÊñ≠Ê≠£Âú®ËøõË°åÁöÑ‰ΩéÊä¢Âç†‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ß‰∏≠Êñ≠ÁöÑ„ÄÇ
  • Êä¢Âç†‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÁõ∏ÂêåÁöÑ‰∏≠Êñ≠ÔºåÈ´òÂìçÂ∫î‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ß‰∏çÂèØ‰ª•ÊâìÊñ≠‰ΩéÂìçÂ∫î‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÁöÑ‰∏≠Êñ≠„ÄÇ
  • Êä¢Âç†‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÁõ∏ÂêåÁöÑ‰∏≠Êñ≠ÔºåÂΩì‰∏§‰∏™‰∏≠Êñ≠ÂêåÊó∂ÂèëÁîüÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºåÂì™‰∏™ÂìçÂ∫î‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÈ´òÔºåÂì™‰∏™ÂÖàÊâßË°å„ÄÇ
  • Â¶ÇÊûú‰∏§‰∏™‰∏≠Êñ≠ÁöÑÊä¢Âç†‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÂíåÂìçÂ∫î‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÈÉΩÊòØ‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÁöÑËØùÔºåÂàôÁúãÂì™‰∏™‰∏≠Êñ≠ÂÖàÂèëÁîüÂ∞±ÂÖàÊâßË°åÔºõ

‰∏æ‰æã

ÂÅáÂÆöËÆæÁΩÆ‰∏≠Êñ≠‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÁªÑ‰∏∫2ÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéËÆæÁΩÆ‰∏≠Êñ≠3(RTC‰∏≠Êñ≠)ÁöÑÊä¢Âç†‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ß‰∏∫2ÔºåÂìçÂ∫î‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ß‰∏∫1„ÄÇ ‰∏≠Êñ≠6ÔºàÂ§ñÈÉ®‰∏≠Êñ≠0ÔºâÁöÑÊä¢Âç†‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ß‰∏∫3ÔºåÂìçÂ∫î‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ß‰∏∫0„ÄÇ‰∏≠Êñ≠7ÔºàÂ§ñÈÉ®‰∏≠Êñ≠1ÔºâÁöÑÊä¢Âç†‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ß‰∏∫2ÔºåÂìçÂ∫î‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ß‰∏∫0„ÄÇ

ÈÇ£‰πàËøô3‰∏™‰∏≠Êñ≠ÁöÑ‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÈ°∫Â∫è‰∏∫Ôºö‰∏≠Êñ≠7>‰∏≠Êñ≠3>‰∏≠Êñ≠6„ÄÇ

ÁâπÂà´ËØ¥Êòé

‰∏ÄËà¨ÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºåÁ≥ªÁªü‰ª£Á†ÅÊâßË°åËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠ÔºåÂè™ËÆæÁΩÆ‰∏ÄÊ¨°‰∏≠Êñ≠‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÂàÜÁªÑÔºåÊØîÂ¶ÇÂàÜÁªÑ2ÔºåËÆæÁΩÆÂ•ΩÂàÜÁªÑ‰πãÂêé‰∏ÄËà¨‰∏ç‰ºöÂÜçÊîπÂèòÂàÜÁªÑ„ÄÇÈöèÊÑèÊîπÂèòÂàÜÁªÑ‰ºöÂØºËá¥‰∏≠Êñ≠ÁÆ°ÁêÜÊ∑∑‰π±ÔºåÁ®ãÂ∫èÂá∫Áé∞ÊÑèÊÉ≥‰∏çÂà∞ÁöÑÊâßË°åÁªìÊûú„ÄÇ

‰∏≠Êñ≠‰ΩøËÉΩÂØÑÂ≠òÂô®ÁªÑÔºöISER[8]

‰∏≠Êñ≠Â§±ËÉΩÂØÑÂ≠òÂô®ÁªÑÔºöICER[8]

entry.title: „ÄêSTM32„ÄëSTM32Êó∂ÈíüÁ≥ªÁªüÂíåÊó∂ÈíüÁ≥ªÁªüÂàùÂßãÂåñÂáΩÊï∞

Bit & Byte

  • 1Â≠óËäÇ(ByteÔºâ = 8‰Ωç(bit)

  • Âú®ASCIIÁ†Å‰∏≠Ôºå‰∏Ä‰∏™Ëã±ÊñáÂ≠óÊØç(‰∏çÂàÜÂ§ßÂ∞èÂÜô)Âç†‰∏Ä‰∏™Â≠óËäÇÁöÑÁ©∫Èó¥Ôºå‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏≠ÊñáÊ±âÂ≠óÂç†‰∏§‰∏™Â≠óËäÇÁöÑÁ©∫Èó¥

  • Á¨¶Âè∑ÔºöËã±ÊñáÊ†áÁÇπÂç†‰∏Ä‰∏™Â≠óËäÇÔºå‰∏≠ÊñáÊ†áÁÇπÂç†‰∏§‰∏™Â≠óËäÇ

  • 1ÂçÉÂêâÂ≠óËäÇÔºàTB,TerabyteÔºâ=1024ÂêâÂ≠óËäÇÔºà2ÁöÑ40Ê¨°ÊñπÂ≠óËäÇÔºâÔºà1TB=1024GBÔºâ

  • 1ÂêâÂ≠óËäÇÔºàGB,GigabyteÔºâ=1024ÂÖÜÂ≠óËäÇÔºà2ÁöÑ30Ê¨°ÊñπÂ≠óËäÇÔºâÔºà1GB=1024MBÔºâ

  • 1ÂÖÜÂ≠óËäÇÔºàMB,MegabyteÔºâ=1024ÂçÉÂ≠óËäÇÔºà2ÁöÑ20Ê¨°ÊñπÂ≠óËäÇÔºâÔºà1MB=1024KBÔºâ

  • 1Â≠óËäÇÔºàByteÔºâ= 8‰ΩçÔºàbitÔºâ

ËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰Ωç

‰∫åËøõÂà∂Êï∞Á≥ªÁªü‰∏≠ÔºåÊØè‰∏™0Êàñ1Â∞±ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰Ωç(bit)Ôºå‰ΩçÊòØÊï∞ÊçÆÂ≠òÂÇ®ÁöÑÊúÄÂ∞èÂçï‰Ωç„ÄÇÂÖ∂‰∏≠8bitÂ∞±Áß∞‰∏∫‰∏Ä‰∏™Â≠óËäÇÔºàByteÔºâ„ÄÇËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫‰∏≠ÁöÑCPU‰ΩçÊï∞ÊåáÁöÑÊòØCPU‰∏ÄÊ¨°ËÉΩÂ§ÑÁêÜÁöÑÊúÄÂ§ß‰ΩçÊï∞„ÄÇ‰æãÂ¶Ç32‰ΩçËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ÁöÑCPU‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÊúÄÂ§öËÉΩÂ§ÑÁêÜ32‰ΩçÊï∞ÊçÆ„ÄÇ

entry.title: ËÑ∏‰∏äÂêÑÈÉ®‰ΩçÈïøÁóòÁóòÁöÑÂéüÂõ†ÂèäË∞ÉÁêÜÊñπÊ≥ïÊ±áÊÄª
entry.content:
È¢ùÂ§¥ÁóòÁä∂ÂÜµÔºöÊúâÂèØËÉΩÊòØÂéãÂäõÂ§™Â§ßÔºåÂÆπÊòìËÑæÊ∞î‰∏çÂ•ΩÔºåÈÄ†ÊàêÂøÉÁÅ´ÂíåË°ÄÊ∂≤Âæ™ÁéØÊúâÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇ

ÊîπÂñÑÔºöÂ∫îÂÖªÊàêÊó©Áù°Êó©Ëµ∑ÁöÑ‰π†ÊÉØÔºåËÆ©Áù°Áú†ÂÖÖË∂≥ÔºåÂπ∂Â§öÂñùÊ∞¥„ÄÇ

Âç∞Â†ÇÁóòÁä∂ÂÜµÔºöÂá∫Áé∞Âú®‰∏§ÁúâÊ≠£‰∏≠Èó¥ÁöÑÁóòÁóòÔºåÈÄöÂ∏∏ÊúâËÉ∏Èó∑„ÄÅÂøÉÂæã‰∏çÊï¥„ÄÅÂøÉÊÇ∏Á≠âÊØõÁóÖ„ÄÇ

ÊîπÂñÑÔºö‰∏çË¶ÅÂ∞ùËØïÂ§™ËøáÊøÄÁÉàÁöÑËøêÂä®ÔºåË¶ÅÈÅøÂÖçÁÉü„ÄÅÈÖíÁ≠âÂà∫ÊøÄÊÄßÁöÑÈ£üÂìÅ„ÄÇ

ÂèëÈ´ªÁóòÁä∂ÂÜµÔºöÂõ†‰∏∫Âç∏Â¶ÜÊ≤°ÊúâÂç∏Âπ≤ÂáÄÔºåÈÄ†ÊàêÊØõÂ≠îÂ†µÂ°ûÊ≤≥Ê±°ÊüìÔºåÂÆπÊòìÂú®ËæÉÈó∑ÁöÑÂèëÈ´ªÊàñÁúâÈó¥ÂΩ¢ÊàêÁªÜÂ∞èÁóòÁóò„ÄÇ

ÊîπÂñÑÔºöÂä†Âº∫Âç∏Â¶ÜÂíåÊ∏ÖÊ¥ÅÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÔºå‰∏ÄÂÆöË¶ÅÂΩªÂ∫ïÊêìÊèâÂπ≤ÂáÄÔºåÊØèÊòüÊúüÂÅö‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÂéªËßíË¥®Â∑•‰ΩúÔºåÊä•Á∫∏ÁöÆËÑÇËÖ∫È°∫ÁïÖ„ÄÇ

ÈºªÁøºÁóòÁä∂ÂÜµÔºöÁ™ÅÁÑ∂ÂÜíÂá∫ÁöÑËÇøÂ§ßÁóòÁóòÔºåÂèØËÉΩÊòØÂçµÂ∑¢Êú∫ËÉΩÊàñËÄÖÁîüÊÆñÁ≥ªÁªüÊúâÂÖ≥„ÄÇ

ÊîπÂñÑÔºö‰∏çË¶ÅËøáÂ∫¶Á∫µÊ¨≤ÊàñÁ¶ÅÊ¨≤ÔºåÂ∞ΩÈáèËµ∞Âá∫Êà∑Â§ñÔºå‰∫´ÂèóÈôçÁöÑËá™ÁÑ∂ÁéØÂ¢É„ÄÇ

ÈºªÂ§¥ÁóòÁä∂ÂÜµÔºöÂèØËÉΩÊòØËÉÉÁÅ´ËøáÂ§ßÔºåÊ∂àÂåñÁ≥ªÁªüÂºÇÂ∏∏„ÄÇ

ÊîπÂñÑÔºöÂ∞ëÂêÉÂÜ∞ÂÜ∑È£üÁâ©ÔºåÂØíÊÄßÈ£üÂìÅÂÆπÊòìÂºïËµ∑ËÉÉÈÖ∏ÂàÜÊ≥åÔºåÈÄ†ÊàêËÉÉÁÅ´ËøáÂ§ß„ÄÇ
